intro: Lycopus europaeus f. pusillus, commonly known as narrow-leaved water horehound, is a low-growing perennial herb native to Europe. It typically reaches heights of 10–30 cm and features small, opposite, elliptical leaves with hairy surfaces. The plant produces clusters of tiny, blue to purple flowers in late summer, which are followed by small, oval berries. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodland edges and stream banks. Its botanical characteristics make it a valuable species for ecological studies and traditional herbal use.
